description.narrative: Development problemThe project will target people in 11 different indigenous language groups especially women and youth. These language groups consist of 632 000 people in the North West West Centre East and Far North Regions of Cameroon.All chosen langua ge groups belongs to minorities and therefore are more underdeveloped than others. They suffer from poverty malnutrition health issues and poor education. Lack of education results in people being unaware of their rights.The core problem among these peopl e is their poor access to appropriate education and training.Overall objectivesThe immediate objective of this project is to increase the communities and individuals in their own capacity to deal with their own problems. The goal is to empower unskilled yo ung people and adults with their own language. Through the program their reading skills will develop and they will learn to use learn to put their reading to practical use.Another immediate goal is to strengthen the partner?s and village committees? capaci ty to act as competent development actors.The goal of the project is to seek improved quality of life for minority people groups in Cameroon by maximizing the opportunities for self-directed development. Cross-cutting development objectivesGender equality Reduction of inequality and Climate sustainability will be taught in the classes. These issues are part of the learning material. In addition they will be taken into consideration in all the activities. E.g. chosing the main target people and a part of the advocacy .Structure This program will not create any new organizational structures but rather strengthen existing ones.The main beneficiariesThe goal is to reach the youth and adults who have completed basic mother-tongue literacy classes. In particular w omen are included All the beneficiaries belong to minority ethnic groups. These people have a very low education background or no education at all. Often they are marginalized because of a language problem.The key activities1. Translation of the excising t ested learning material into 11 languages2. Advocacy3. Training teachers and staff4. 9-month functional-literacy course in 11 language groups total 46 classes in the second and third project years. In each class there will be about 20 students.5. Capacity building of the partner as a significant development actor6. Monitoring
